Award.AwardTitle: Broadband Seismological Investigations of Earth Structure and Earthquake Sources
Award.AbstractNarration:
The UCSC seismological research program supervised by Professor Thorne Lay uses global broadband digital seismic data (as well as high-rate GPS data and tsunami recordings) to address fundamental questions about earth structure and earthquake rupture processes. Quantitative analysis of recorded wave-fields generated by earthquakes will be used to address the following fundamental questions: (1) joint inversions of high-rate GPS data, broadband seismic body waves and surface waves, and tsunami observations will be undertaken for recent huge earthquakes in Chile, Mentawai, and off-Sumatra, for the purpose of understanding how the ruptures grew and how the faults slipped in each case; (2) spectral analysis of earthquakes on and near plate boundary megathrust faults will be conducted using strong-motion and teleseismic recordings of seismic wave vibrations to further develop and test a recently introduced model of depth-dependent variations in seismic radiation from megathrust faults; (3) stacking and migration of seismograms from deep focus earthquakes will be performed to develop images of upper mantle reflectivity and heterogeneity spectrum in the vicinity of subduction zones; and (4) new stacking and migration approaches will be applied to imaging of deep mantle scattering from structures near the core-mantle boundary and near mantle down-wellings and up-wellings to better characterize the thermal and dynamical nature of these planetary features.

This overall research effort will engage the PI and two graduate students in both earthquake source and earth structure research problems using quantitative analysis of various wave types generated by earthquake sources. We hope to fully characterize the depth-dependence of seismic radiation from earthquakes, and to evaluate the implications for earthquake shaking hazard. We anticipate sustaining progress in characterizing important dynamical processes associated with the Earth's major boundary layers near the surface and near the core-mantle boundary, drawing upon this information to understand the heat flow in the Earth and the dynamical processes that drive earthquakes and volcanoes at the surface.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported graduate student and postdoctoral training and research in the use of global seismological recordings by broadband ground motion instruments applied to study earthquake and earth structure problems.  A particular focus of the past 5 years for this grant has been on detailed analysis of rupture processes for large earthquakes, and assessment of the influence of the space-time history of slip on the fault on the stress change in the surrounding medium that results in triggered doublet events, aftershocks, and seafloor deformation leading to tsunami generation.  We have worked closely with groups with expertise in tsunami modeling (University of Hawaii, Manoa) and geodetic modeling (University of Alaska) to develop joint inversions or complementary constraints on rupture models from seismic, geodetic, and tsunami data analysis. This approach has proved particularly important and effective to constraining the shallow up-dip distribution of slip on offshore plate boundary megathrust faults. We demonstrated that slip extending to the trench with very large magnitude can account for the full set of seismic, geodetic and tsunami observations for the 2011 Tohoku and 2010 Chile earthquakes.  Our contributions have been at the leading edge of quantitative, published studies of all major and great earthquakes throughout the grant period and we have extended the analyses back to 1990, spanning the time of bountiful global broadband seismic data availability.  We have actively engaged in sythesis of the scaling behavior and regional influences on the large earthquake ruptures. Using the suite of fault slip models, we have pursued analysis of the influence of stress drop and radiated energy on the aftershock sequences, and we have established hitherto unrecognized depth-dependence of the aftershock sequences for large interplate ruptures that appears to primarily be the result of total shear stress relaxation for ruptures of the shallowest megathrust.  For earth structure studies, we have contributed major reviews of deep mantle structure and the post-perovskite phase transition and have modeled deep mantle reflections from the vicinity of the core-mantle boundary. The primary intellectual merit of this research has been in improving our understanding of large earthquake ruptures at a fundamental level using all available data sets that provide complementary information.  Synthesis of many individual event studies underlies efforts to advance earthquake forecasting and mitigation, and improvement of tsunami warning systems. Training of students in interdisciplinary research is cultivating a next generation of broadly based scientists who can draw upon all available data to achieve the best representation of earthquake sources.
